timeline.author: maririos

replies.bodyText:
Java has a guideline where we're expected to have our pipeline policies in the public API. We allow customers to roll their own pipeline if they wish, so making these inaccessible from the public API would make that more difficult.
@JonathanGiles to point to the guideline since I'm having trouble finding it. (Or to add it if it is missing)
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText: The wording might be unclear but it's here - "DO provide a suitable authentication policy that authenticates the HTTP request in the HTTP pipeline when using non-standard credentials. This includes custom connection strings, if supported."
replies.author: JonathanGiles

replies.bodyText: In this case I would push to move up the shared Azure.Core implementation of a generic auth policy as in the discussion below, so we don't have these types left around as artifacts in libraries that GA before it's available
replies.author: schaabs

replies.bodyText: If it is okay, I'm going to merge this PR as it keeps hitting merge conflicts due to its scope and file an issue to follow-up on a generic policy.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText:
So this means that every client needs to implement it's own policy, is that correct?
Wondering if we could add a generic policy to Azure Core too
timeline.author: maririos

replies.bodyText:
I was discussing this with @JonathanGiles and we didn't strongly lean on one design or the other. I left the library specific policies in place given they are in preview and adding this into Azure Core would likely require it being part of the public API which could GA it sooner (Java doesn't have a good friends assembly or internal that .NET leverages).
@JonathanGiles any concern around making this a generic Azure Core policy that uses the credential and a header string? We do something conceptually similar with the RetryPolicy where we can pass a retry header to look for on the response.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

replies.bodyText:
I left the library specific policies in place given they are in preview

Note that Text Analytics is going to GA in April, so if we could add the policy to Core now, that will be great for TA.
replies.author: maririos

replies.bodyText: Couldn't the library specific policies be internal to the package, or added under implementation? Then you can always update them to use an implementation exposed by core at some point in the future.
replies.author: schaabs

replies.bodyText: Yes, this could be done but goes a bit against the response above around why the policy is in the public API.
replies.author: alzimmermsft

timeline.bodyText: Could you use one check of CoreUtil.isNullOrEmpty() here?
timeline.author: sima-zhu

replies.bodyText: Definitely could but our guidelines state if we expect a non-null parameter and we get null a NullPointerException should be thrown (the Objects.requireNonNull check) and then if we get a value that we don't expect that isn't null throw a IllegalArgumentException (the isEmpty check).
replies.author: alzimmermsft
